body:
Verified this fixed the python build on my machine.

R: @charlesccychen

I did a big refactor of the tests: I deduplicated UTests and ITests code and introduce a new `elasticsearch-tests-commmon` and `elasticsearch-tests-parent` modules:

Create ElasticsearchIOTestCommon to hold test code (UTests and ITests)
Move tests utils to elasticsearch-tests-common
Define ES_INDEX and ES_TYPE only in ITests and UTests classes and use ConnectionConfiguration everywhere else
Simplify and rename ElasticsearchTestDataset to ElasticsearchIOITCommon
@ssisk please note the last point for the ITests automation
@jkff PTAL

Sorry about the delay.

Could you explain why this change is needed and create a JIRA issue ?

Localhost option is to enable users to test against a locally running Datastore. We pass that option everywhere when we create a datastore client except in `GqlQueryTranslateFn`. 

Thanks for making this change, LGTM.

@staslev Please review
retest this please

The following changes were performed as part of this PR:

1. `TimeDomain.PROCESSING_TIME` based timers are always passed in to `ReduceFnRunner#onTimers(timers)` regardless of the watermark position.
2. Timers are no longer deleted from `SparkTimerInternals` by (what used to be) `SparkTimerInternals#getTimersReadyToProcess()`, they are deleted by GC timer.
3. `SparkTimerInternals#getTimersReadyToProcess(...)` was renamed to `filterEligibleForProcessing(...)` and moved to `SparkGroupAlsoByWindowViaWindowSet` since it is the one who determines what *eligible* for processing actually means.

R: @jasonkuster

Technically, this is a bugfix since in exceedingly rare situations you could get DoFn state bleeding between steps. So we need it regardless of the performance impact.

As for removing the overhead of naively going to/from proto willy nilly, highly unscientific measurements on my desktop look roughly like wordcount on King Lear takes:

2.1.0: ~10s
master: ~45s
this change: ~30s

I'll continue removing proto wrangling from evaluator instantiation after finishing up this PR.

So it seems like I'm might be release managing for the Apache Spark project's next minor release which might take me away from having the time to work on beam until the release is out. If it's possible to get this reviewed before things get heavy on the Spark release would be awesome, but if not I understand.
R: @tgroh OK fixed up stateful tests and ready. I did not go so far as to merge the evaluator factories as I think that might be a sweeping change with unknown scope.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13240977/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13240977)

Coverage decreased (-0.1%) to 69.371% when pulling **4649ae2e326c3b1d58dbaada8bb03a9c109598fc on kennknowles:ParDoEvaluatorFactory-cache** into **8e391d94f7a4ddc0dbbc7ec54d42df5b6cb7903c on apache:master**.

Running this on all of Shakespeare (5mb) shows a similar improvement on this PR:

2.1.0: 45 seconds
master: 220 seconds
this PR: 130 seconds

but not good benchmarking methodology anyhow. The slowdown is still massive.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13242235/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13242235)

Coverage decreased (-0.03%) to 69.487% when pulling **2c018cd471f62e7d6e4d5f61b461c9c0e8cb9247 on kennknowles:ParDoEvaluatorFactory-cache** into **8e391d94f7a4ddc0dbbc7ec54d42df5b6cb7903c on apache:master**.

On your high-level comment: I decided to go for option 3 but improve error reporting - see changes in PCollectionViews. I can't think of a reliable way to find which PCollectionView's inside a closure will actually be accessed; and there might be PCollectionView's captured not in the closure itself but transitively through its member variables etc. - this also rules out option 2. I think good error messages are the only feasible way.

I added error checking for ParDo test for accessing from StartBundle/FinishBundle.

Deprecation of the methods you indicated will follow as part of the parent JIRA, but shouldn't be done in this PR until Dataflow runner supports UsesImplicitSideInputs.

Note that, since I changed PCollectionView interface, I had to add a serialVersionUID matching the old value to SimplePCollectionView - otherwise mismatch of runners-core-construction jars between the pipeline and the worker image caused it to fail with NonSerializableException's about this class.

Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-2950 about state.
R: @charlesccychen
Fast path seems brittle compared to understanding the lifetime of an object and caching it appropriately from the callers perspective.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13244813/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13244813)

Coverage increased (+0.008%) to 69.521% when pulling **7a10c2a10d76c4f7de0eefdc5be2b07b9c08a1fe on jkff:side-input** into **8e391d94f7a4ddc0dbbc7ec54d42df5b6cb7903c on apache:master**.

This is to unblock 2.2.0. After that, I will be working up a shared fast path for both original and rehydrated RawPTransforms. For the Java direct runner, the only path, as the only possibility for a ParDo will be a `ParDo.MultiOutput` if it hasn't been round-tripped or a `RawParDo` (to be implemented) if it has. This requires infrastructure that won't make 2.2.0.

This translation code will ultimately serve other runners as well, and be used for non-Java, so the `RawParDo` will be the primary path, but will still be efficient regardless of language.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13244875/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13244875)

Coverage decreased (-0.01%) to 69.503% when pulling **af94b7b7a8c0ac0ada222884101ec10127f5b234 on mariapython:retry_tests** into **8e391d94f7a4ddc0dbbc7ec54d42df5b6cb7903c on apache:master**.

Actually, a point worth mentioning is that the object lifetimes are open-ended. Anyone is free to call these methods on a `ParDo.MultiOutput` at any time, and anyone is free to round-trip a pipeline as many times as they want. This code needs to be agnostic.

If you mean that the direct runner should cache the extracted bits so that each call to build a bundle evaluator hits the cache, as it does for the DoFn, that is fine too. But I think we want both and I don't think we need to block 2.2.0 on that.

It is also much easier to make always-efficient paths than to deal with cache policies (in this case we'd likely just be non-evicting).
Please do not conflate this to also be the model for `StateSpec`.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13245064/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13245064)

Coverage decreased (-0.01%) to 69.5% when pulling **9b30bcaa707738da46bd238d3823717e266a8056 on kennknowles:ParDoTranslation-shortcut** into **8e391d94f7a4ddc0dbbc7ec54d42df5b6cb7903c on apache:master**.

If the transform can not be translated finally, an exception will be thrown when translating primitive transform. So I don't think we need to print any WARN log when translating composite transform.

Separating the existing "intrinsic" mode of executing Java SDK pipelines on the FlinkRunner might be helpful in the future to clarify the dependencies.
